Subjective: Headaches for 2 months, worsening. Primarily right-sided, but sometimes diffuse. Occasional nausea at worst, no vomiting. Glare in vision, no flashes of light. Headaches occur at least weekly, lasting several days. Prefers dark, quiet room. Family history of migraines (father) and cluster headaches (grandfather). No known serious family history (tumors). No recent stress, vacations. Reduced coffee intake. Tried paracetamol (PRN, only if unbearable), ibuprofen (worked well). Student (medicine, 2nd year). Impact on daily life: unable to play volleyball, missed social activities. Request: Understand cause (migraine vs. cluster), best course of action.
Objective: BP 120/80. Pulse 50 bpm. Cranial nerves intact. Fingertip-nose test normal. Arm/leg strength good. Romberg's normal. Gait slightly unsteady but manageable. No vital signs mentioned beyond BP and pulse.
Assessment: Suspected migraine. Rule out cluster headache. No signs of secondary headache (e.g., tumor).
Plan:
1. Patient education: Review migraine information on thuisarts.nl. 
2. Pain management: Start paracetamol 4x2 tabs at fixed times at symptom onset. Add ibuprofen if paracetamol insufficient. 
3. Headache diary: Track symptoms, duration, triggers, and response to medication. Print diary for patient. 
4. Follow-up: Return in 4 weeks with diary for review. Return sooner if symptoms worsen significantly or change.
5. Safety netting: Return sooner for worsening or changing symptoms.
